WESTMORELAND — Water at the county-owned Maplewood Nursing Home
is now clean after testing positive for E. coli earlier this week,
On Tuesday, N.H. Department of Environmental Services did a
routine test of the nursing home’s water system, which does not
serve any other buildings in Westmoreland.
That test came back positive for the bacteria and on Wednesday
the nursing home was issued a boil water order.
County Administrator John G. Wozmak said the water is clean now
and the issue appears to have been short lived.
“I don’t know what it was all about but it’s gone now,” Wozmak
said, noting officials will continue to monitor the water.
The boil water order was lifted Friday.
No source was found for the positive E. coli result and it could
have been a false reading, according to Wozmak.
While some E. coli is harmless, unsafe strains of the bacteria
found in water or food can cause severe abdominal cramps, diarrhea
and vomiting, according to the Mayo Clinic website.
Healthy adults usually recover from infection within a week, but
young children and older adults can develop life-threatening kidney
Bottled water and store-bought ice was brought to the nursing
home and all water for cooking purposes was to be boiled. Staff
members were instructed to use hand sanitizer in addition to
washing hands with soap and water.
